@graph.reasoning: The question before us is whether federal labor laws shield such an agreement from antitrust attack.
The immunity before us rests upon what this Court has called the 'nonstatutory' labor exemption from the antitrust laws.

@graph.@id: Meat Cutters v. Jewel Tea Co.
@graph.reasoning: The Court has implied this exemption from federal labor statutes, which set forth a national labor policy favoring free and private collective bargaining.

@graph.@id: San Diego Building Trades Council v. Garmon

@graph.@id: Duplex Printing Press Co. v. Deering
@graph.reasoning: As a matter of history, Congress intended the labor statutes (from which the Court has implied the exemption) in part to adopt the views of dissenting Justices in Duplex Printing Press Co. v. Deering.
Congress, as in 1914, hoped to prevent judicial use of antitrust law to resolve labor disputes-a kind of dispute normally inappropriate for antitrust law resolution.

@graph.@id: Marine Cooks v. PanamaS . S. Co.
@graph.reasoning: The implicit ('nonstatutory') exemption interprets the labor statutes in light of Congress' intent to leave labor disputes to the processes of collective bargaining and to the National Labor Relations Board.
